Name: Arecibo
Remarks: 305 m (1,001 ft) Second largest single dish spherical reflector radiotelescope in the world. Structural issues lead to the decision to dismantle the structure. Before this could be done the instrument platform collapsed in December 2020.[53]

Name: Goldstone
Remarks: One of the most sensitive radars in the world. DSS-14. Supplies circular polarization

Name: Green Bank
Remarks: World's largest 100-metre (330 ft) fully steerable single-dish radio telescope

Name: Very Large Array
Remarks: Array of 27 dishes. Part of NRAO.

Name: FAST
Remarks: 500m radio telescope, the world's largest filled-aperture radio telescope, operating range 70–3000 MHz.[17] Five hundred meter Aperture Spherical Telescope (FAST)

Name: Canberra DSS-43
Remarks: 1x70 m dish, 3x34 m dishes, operated by CSIRO on behalf of NASA.[23] 400kW can be used in emergency mode but only above 17°, normally 20kW Canberra Deep Space Communication Complex (CDSCC)

Name: EDSCC
Remarks: There is a transmision antenna with 25meter diameter. It transmits 8 kW of power on 5 GHz and 80 kW on 770 MHz. Eastern Deep Space Communications Center

Name: Usuda Deep Space Center
Remarks: X-band and S-band radio waves are used for communicating with space probes. K-band will also be used in the future.

Name: Effelsberg
Remarks: 100 m fully steerable dish operated by Max Planck Institut für Radioastronomie, operates at 395 MHz to 95 GHz

Name: Parkes
Remarks: 64 m telescope (2nd largest movable dish in the Southern Hemisphere), operated by CSIRO as part of the ATNF (Australia Telescope National Facility).[25]

Name: AVN-Ghana
Remarks: 32 metre (104 foot) single dish, first of African VLBI Network[1]
